awd_titl_txt: Multiscale and Hybridizable Discontinuous Galerkin Methods for Dispersive Equations and Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concentrates on the development of novel computational methods for efficiently solving dispersive equations and systems, including the time-independent Schrodinger equations and Korteweg-de Vries (KdV) type equations in multidimensional spaces and systems.  Schrodinger equations play a central role in the study of quantum mechanical systems and are widely used in the simulation of quantum transport in nanoscale semiconductor devices. The proposed multiscale method for Schrodinger equations will have a positive impact in the study of quantum mechanics and great potential in applications to ultrafast, low consumption and high functionality nanoscale semiconductor devices. KdV type equations and systems have wide applications in various fields such as fluid mechanics, nonlinear optics, acoustics, plasma physics, and Bose-Einstein condensates. The proposed method for KdV type equations and systems will help understand theoretically unresolved issues and provide accurate and efficient numerical tools for simulation of nonlinear waves in applications. 
 
The proposed research includes the following topics, (1) development and analysis of multiscale discontinuous Galerkin (DG) methods for Schrodinger equations in 1D, system, and 2D for the simulation of nanoscale semiconductor structures on coarse meshes, (2) design and error analysis of hybridizable discontinuous Galerkin (HDG) methods for solving multidimensional KdV type equations and KdV type systems, and (3) design of IMEX HDG-DG schemes for efficiently solving KdV type nonlinear equations and systems. To efficiently resolve highly oscillatory solutions of Schrodinger equations on coarse meshes, the multiscale DG methods will incorporate the oscillatory nature of the solutions and thus the multiple scales into the non-polynomial basis functions. For KdV type equations in multi-dimensions and systems, the PI will devise new HDG methods, study their convergence and conservation properties, and combine them with other DG methods in IMEX scheme to achieve high-order solutions both in time and in space and avoid overly small time-step sizes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award is for the development of novel algorithms for accurate and efficient simulation of dispersive equations and systems such as Schrodinger equations and Korteweg-de Vries (KdV) type equations and systems. These problems have not only significant importance in theoretical studies but also wide applications in areas such as electrical engineering, fluid mechanics, acoustics, and plasma physics.

The P.I. worked with her collaborators and successfully achieved the goals stated in the grant proposal. First, they developed and analyzed high-order multiscale discontinuous Galerkin (DG) methods with non-polynomial basis functions for time-independent Schrodinger equations in one- and two-dimensional spaces. The methods converge on coarse meshes where traditional DG methods fail. On fine meshes, the multiscale DG methods achieve optimal orders of convergence and the errors are several magnitudes smaller than those of traditional DG methods. So, these new methods are efficient tools for solving problems that have multiple scales and high frequency wave solutions. Second, the P.I. and her collaborators designed a novel DG method for the simulation of solitary wave solutions to KdV type equations. The key feature of the method is the simultaneous conservation of the mass, energy and Hamiltonian that are preserved by exact solutions of all KdV equations. This is the first DG method that conserves all these three quantities, a property critical for the accurate long-time simulation of solitary waves. Their novel idea of achieving conservation properties can serve as a framework for designing physics-conserving numerical methods for other types of problems. Third, they devised a new DG method for solving KdV type systems and the method can achieve high-order accuracy and conserve invariants that are preserved by exact solutions.

Besides devising novel competitive algorithms for numerical simulation in applications in science and engineering, the grant also contributes to the training of next generation of computational scientists. A female graduate student from our interdisciplinary doctoral program was supported by this award. By participating into the project, she learned about the design and analysis of numerical method and improved her computational programming skills. The results she obtained from this project were included in her PhD thesis. The research experience and expertise she gained through the project will help her thrive in her future career.
